lines:
September 26, 1912. 
Tommie Sxon V3 isos aids of

paTwoy vleressie Viev

Ar. S. C. Luk,

224 North Wayne Street,

Angola, Indiana.

My bar Luk:

I deeply appreciate your better, which reached me this morning.

It is good to hear from you again, though I am more sorry than I can tell 
you that you have had such hard luck lately and have been physically incapac -
itsted for your work. Let me congratulate you on your prospects of an early 
recovery, which I trust may be complete. Don't take any chances on bridges

in the future.

Yes, it is true that I am planning to go abroad in the near future,

as the Trustees have allowed me a year's leave of absence for this purpose.

I had earnestly hoped that this year wauld furnish me the long desired opporo

tunity to visit India, where my family lived for fifteen years, and your own

country, where now I feel that I have many friends. Unfortunately the expense 
which such a trip would involve seems likely to be wholly out of reach of my 
pocketbook, and I fear that I will here to content myself with drifting about

Europe.

During my absence dr. Janes C. Sawyer, our Treasurer, will take charge 
of funds which I have handled heretofore in my agent account. You may therefore 
romit direct to him in case your father sends you the required funds. Don't let 
the matter worry you, however, for I am satisfied that the obligation will be met 
in due season. Just now you have probably had to face extra expenses, and the

strain must have been a bit severe.

Please accept my heartiest good wishes for the new school year just

opening.

I shall hope to hear from you it not actually see you, when I return

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter expressing regret for Luk's injury and stating he will go abroad on a one-year leave. He had hoped to visit India and China, but due to financial contraints, he will be in Europe. James C. Sawyer, Treasurer, will be in charge of funding in the agent account.
